div.p:
|NARRATOR|
The Nose of El Capitan

|NARRATOR|
is the most iconic route
in climbing history.

|DEAN POTTER|
Proudest line up the best piece
of rock I've ever seen.

|NARRATOR|
It's also the arena

|NARRATOR|
for the most radical time trial
on the planet.

|DEAN POTTER|
Let's go!

|SEAN LEARY|
It's badass
to have the speed record

|SEAN LEARY|
on the most bitching wall
in the universe.

|NARRATOR|
As a decades old
rivalry heats up...

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
The potential for disaster
is so huge.

|NARRATOR|
...and the need for speed
blows past concerns for safety.

|NARRATOR|
The race for the Nose record
is coming down to the wire.

|DEAN POTTER|
Come on!

|SEAN LEARY|
Oh, that had to have been close.

|NARRATOR|
The wildest places
on the planet.

|MAN 1|
Rock!

|NARRATOR|
The athletes
who live for the challenge.

|MAN 2|
Come on. Stick it, dude.

|PAMELA PACK|
It's like ultimate
fighting with a rock.

|MAN 3|
You have to get over
that primal fear.

|NARRATOR|
From Alpine legends
to unlikely heroes.

|MAN 4|
Three, two, one!

|NARRATOR|
We've brought cameras
to the ends of the Earth.

|NARRATOR|
To capture
these incredible stories.

|MAN 5|
To try to climb
to the center of the universe.

|NARRATOR|
Of victory

|NARRATOR|
failure

|NARRATOR|
and perseverance.

|MAN|
It's time to dig deep.

|MAN 7/MAN 8|
-Come on, you want this.
-Come on now.

|MAN 9|
Yeah!

|NARRATOR|
Join the great adventurers
of our time

|NARRATOR|
as they step into the unknown.

|DEAN POTTER|
No gear, don't fall!

|NARRATOR|
Risking it all,
to achieve the impossible.

|MAN 10|
It's part insanity
and part genius.

|MAN 11|
I'm good!

|NARRATOR|
Welcome to Reel Rock.

|MAN 12|
Oh, yeah, baby!

|OST|
RACE FOR THE NOSE

|VOICE AUDIO|
It is 6:26, stopwatch.

|DEAN POTTER|
Ten, nine, eight,

|DEAN POTTER|
seven, six.

|ALEX HUBER|
[Foreign language]

|HANS FLORINE|
Five. Four.

|YUJI HIRAYAMA|
[Foreign language]

|ALEX HUBER|
Go!

|NARRATOR|
In Yosemite Valley,
the race is on.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
One of the greatest challenges
in modern climbing

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
is the speed record on the Nose.

|NARRATOR|
Up a 3,000-foot wall
in under 3 hours.

|HAN FLORINE|
It is the most badass
competition there is.

|NARRATOR|
The Nose route of El Capitan

|NARRATOR|
has become a speedway for
the masters of Yosemite granite.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Oh, it's such
an Olympic marathon.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Measuring some of greatest
climbers against each other.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
Yosemite climbing
has always been about

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
inspired by
what other people are doing,

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
try to take it
to that next level.

|THOMAS HUBER|
I'm swinging!

|ALEX HUBER|
You got it!

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
The goal of speed climbing

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
is to get from the base
of the root to the top,

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
as quickly as you can.
Anything goes.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
Pulling on gear.
Stepping on somebody.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
The watch stops when
the second guy tags that tree.

|DEAN POTTER|
Now the record's at a point

|DEAN POTTER|
where if we have to push it
further, it's quite dangerous.

|THOMAS HUBER|
I can show you 10 places
on the wall where you can die.

|ALEX HUBER|
No gear! Don't fall!

|THOMAS HUBER|
It's coming close
to a certain limit.

|SEAN LEARY|
Over half a mile
of vertical rock.

|SEAN LEARY|
Now the speed record is 2 hours
and 37 minutes. What's next?

|HANS FLORINE|
I think this record will last
for a good long time.

|DEAN POTTER|
I think it is possible to break
the record by a large amount.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Dean Potter and Hans Florine.

|MAN 13|
You want it, Hansy?

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
After all these years, still
battling it out on the Nose.

|HANS FLORINE|
As much as people want to say
that they're not competitive,

|HANS FLORINE|
it's a bunch of shit.

|DEAN POTTER|
Racing with Hans,
it disgusts me.

|MAN 14|
You guys think Hans is gonna be
psyched to come back?

|DEAN POTTER|
I don't give a fuck about Hans.

|DEAN POTTER|
Want me to break your camera,
dude?

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Yeah, if you can have
the fastest record

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
on the best route
in the universe,

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
we gotta do that, you know.

|NARRATOR|
Over half a century ago

|NARRATOR|
The Nose was first climbed
by Warren Harding.

|NARRATOR|
In a colossal siege
that lasted nine months.

|NARRATOR|
Two years later,

|NARRATOR|
Royal Robbins climbed
the same route in only 6-days.

|NARRATOR|
Then in 1975,
a team lead by Jim Bridwell

|NARRATOR|
left the bivouac gear behind

|NARRATOR|
and scaled the entire Nose route
in a single day.

|NARRATOR|
But the race for the Nose

|NARRATOR|
really found its stride
in the Lycra-clad '90s.

|NARRATOR|
When Hans Florine
got in on the game.

|HANS FLORINE|
I'm Hans Florine.

|HANS FLORINE|
I'm known
for having the speed record

|HANS FLORINE|
on the Nose of El Capitan.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Hans came out as
an all-American pole vaulter.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
He has a real competitive sight,
you know.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Hans was really pursuing
the speed climbing competitions.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Come up to me, he's like,

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
"Do you wanna go break the
record on the Nose with me?"

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
And I'm like, "Yeah, sure!"

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
You say you're the
fastest climber in the world?

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Let's go do it.
Let's see you back it up."

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
I wasn't ready for
Hans' entourage

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
that he brought with him.

|MAN 15|
How you guys feeling
this morning?

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
We are feeling good.
We are feeling bad.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
We are feeling fast.

|HANS FLORINE|
Real fast.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Now we pulled off an 8:11 time

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
without really
trying that hard even.

|NARRATOR|
Over the next year,

|NARRATOR|
Hans queued up
a string of Yosemite hard men

|NARRATOR|
to help him
bring the Nose record down,

|NARRATOR|
including the legendary
Peter Croft.

|PETER CROFT|
then I've got
the whole afternoon free

|PETER CROFT|
to do something else.

|PETER CROFT|
Whereas for Hans,
the record was everything.

|SEAN LEARY|
Peter and Hans set
the exceptionally proud time

|SEAN LEARY|
of four hours and 22 minutes,
which stood for over a decade.

|SEAN LEARY|
Until Dean Potter
entered the scene.

|DEAN POTTER|
When I first came to the valley,
as with most young climbers,

|DEAN POTTER|
I just wanted to prove myself.

|DEAN POTTER|
Climbing these walls
as fast as humanly possible

|DEAN POTTER|
was the way I saw
that I could do that.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
With Dean up there,

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
something was happening
that I wasn't a part of.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
And I wanted to be a part of it.

|DEAN POTTER|
Me and Timmy O'Neill,
we did a few climbs together.

|DEAN POTTER|
All of a sudden we're like,
"Let's go for the Nose."

|NARRATOR|
The Potter-O'Neill team
raced up the Nose

|NARRATOR|
and took it under four hours,

|NARRATOR|
toppling Hans'
decade-long reign.

|HANS FLORINE|
I was itchy.

|HANS FLORINE|
I thought it'd be fun to try
to break the record back.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
Ten years it took for somebody
to break that record,

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
and in less than 10-days,
Hans comes and breaks it again.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
The guy was merciless.

|DEAN POTTER|
Hans thrives on competition.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
So Dean and I are like,
"Okay, cool, it's on.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
We'll answer back."
So then we went back.

|SEAN LEARY|
Like two days after,
Dean's back up there with Timmy,

|SEAN LEARY|
smashing the record again with
their three hours and 24 minutes.

|HANS FLORINE|
Pretty like, "Slap, look, we can
beat you guys by 30 minutes."

|HANS FLORINE|
It was pretty cool.

|SEAN LEARY|
And then Hans is just like,
"No, I'm taking it back."

|SEAN LEARY|
Dean and Hans,

|SEAN LEARY|
they bring out this weird
competitive side in each other.

|PETER CROFT|
I remember Dean saying,
you know,

|PETER CROFT|
he was competitive with Hans but
he didn't want to be competitive

|PETER CROFT|
and everybody has
those feelings, I guess.

|DEAN POTTER|
The competition
of speed climbing

|DEAN POTTER|
hasn't made me feel good.

|DEAN POTTER|
I love the action
of speed climbing,

|DEAN POTTER|
but then trying to beat somebody
else, that's not what I do.

|HANS FLORINE|
There's a perception
by people out there,

|HANS FLORINE|
there was friction between
me and Dean, which there was.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
You take an already tense
situation, speed climbing,

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
and then you add
the focus of the media.

|WOMAN|
Unbelievable, Hans.
Welcome to Conversations.

|WOMAN|
You got to be kidding me.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
And It just becomes too much.

|DEAN POTTER|
With Hans, it was like
this little dog humping my leg.

|DEAN POTTER|
I hated the fact that it brought
out the little dog in me.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
Dean comes from a background
of climbing very soulfully.

|DEAN POTTER|
Competition like that.

|DEAN POTTER|
I haven't found
a healthy place for it.

|DEAN POTTER|
I think Hans has.

|HANS FLORINE|
Yeah, competition
I believe is super healthy.

|HANS FLORINE|
As much as people like
climbers aren't competitive,

|HANS FLORINE|
they are competing with the rock
or with themselves.

|HANS FLORINE|
It's a bunch of shit, you know.

|DEAN POTTER|
It is the way humans are that
we want to one-up each other.

|DEAN POTTER|
We want to stand on top
or be number one.

|DEAN POTTER|
But I started climbing
to remove myself from that.

|DEAN POTTER|
At a certain point I just
pulled back, and I was like,

|DEAN POTTER|
"No, speed climbing
is not for me."

|NARRATOR|
Put off by the bad vibes
on El Capitan,

|NARRATOR|
Potter relinquished the Nose
record to his long-time rival.

|PETER CROFT|
Once Dean dropped out,
Hans totally owned that record.

|PETER CROFT|
He was Mr. Nose.

|HANS FLORINE|
It's gonna be really hard for
someone to go faster than us.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
Hans posted this time

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
that no one touched
for a really long time.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
Until the Huber brothers
got involved.

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
No way, it's the Hubers,

|TIMMY O'NEILL|
two of the most famous climbers
in the entire world.

|NARRATOR|
In 2007,

|NARRATOR|
the Nose race was shaken up

|NARRATOR|
by German climbing stars,
Alex and Thomas Huber.

|THOMAS HUBER|
First we thought speed climbing
is a stupid thing,

|THOMAS HUBER|
or it's an American thing.

|THOMAS HUBER|
I don't want to say American
it's the same like stupid,

|THOMAS HUBER|
but we don't like it.

|ALEX HUBER|
But we found out that it's
real sport and we like sports,

|ALEX HUBER|
and of course we are ambitious
and we want to do this.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
Well, the Huber brothers

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
came with one of
the larger film crews

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
that's ever been in Yosemite.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
They brought
a whole new approach,

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
which is really working out
every move for weeks at a time.

|THOMAS HUBER|
We trained really hard
on the Nose.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
They were putting in
some fast times,

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
getting close to the record.

|HANS FLORINE|
I was on the wall
the day the Huber brothers

|HANS FLORINE|
were on schedule to bust
the record by 18-minutes.

|ALEX HUBER|
We just wanted to make
the first real speedy go.

|ALEX HUBER|
And Thomas took a whipper
and landed on the ledge.

|SEAN LEARY|
These are two of the best
climbers in the world,

|SEAN LEARY|
taking whippers, getting hurt
trying to break this record.

|SEAN LEARY|
It shows you
just how hard it is.

|DEAN POTTER|
Speed climbing the Nose is one
of the most a dangerous things

|DEAN POTTER|
that you can do as a climber.

|DEAN POTTER|
There's always
a lot of slack in the rope.

|DEAN POTTER|
If you do fall,
it's gonna be big.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
The potential for disaster
is so huge.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
We talk about it
amongst ourselves.

|STEVE SCHNEIDER|
"One of these guys is gonna get
snuffed out one of these times."

|ALEX HUBER|
That's why it took us two years
to actually do the record.

|THOMAS HUBER/ALEX HUBER|
-Three seasons.
-Three seasons.

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
The Hubers posted a time
that everyone thought,

|CHRIS MCNAMARA|
"All right, now it's not gonna
get done any faster than that."

|THOMAS HUBER|
We can make it five minutes faster,
but it's not worth it.

|THOMAS HUBER|
Because it's super dangerous

|THOMAS HUBER|
and we are happy to survived
our adventure.

|MAN 16|
Yeah.

|NARRATOR|
But no record is safe for long,

|NARRATOR|
from the
insatiable Hans Florine,

|NARRATOR|
who quickly recruited Japanese
rope gun, Yuji Hirayama.

|PETER CROFT|
By far the strongest guy that's
ever speed climbed the Nose,

|PETER CROFT|
Yuji Hirayama.

|HANS FLORINE|
I'm like, "Wow, with Yuji,
I'm gonna nail that record."

|HANS FLORINE|
I think I've held the record

|HANS FLORINE|
on the Nose
longer than anyone else.

|HANS FLORINE|
And so, yeah,
I'd like to have that record.

|SEAN LEARY|
Hans reclaims his title
as "King of the Nose."

|SEAN LEARY|
Two hours and thirty-seven
minutes is blisteringly fast.

|SEAN LEARY|
And that's how the record stands

|SEAN LEARY|
or stood
until Dean and I teamed up.

|DEAN POTTER|
Over the last 10 years, I broke
away from competitive climbing.

|DEAN POTTER|
But my good friend, Sean Leary,

|DEAN POTTER|
would always bring up wanting
to break the Nose record.

|SEAN LEARY|
Over the years,
all these amazing climbers

|SEAN LEARY|
have raced up the Nose
setting standards.

|SEAN LEARY|
I guess I wanted to see
how I could hold up.

|SEAN LEARY|
I just basically went up

|SEAN LEARY|
and started camping out
at Dean's house

|SEAN LEARY|
and annoying
the fuck out of him.

|SEAN LEARY|
I think he's always
in the back of his mind

|SEAN LEARY|
wanted to take
the Nose record back.

|DEAN POTTER|
Those sort of motivations
you can't deny.

|DEAN POTTER|
Now I am 39 years old

|DEAN POTTER|
and I realize that
the clock is ticking.

|DEAN POTTER|
I want to mostly just prove
to myself that I still got it.

|OST|
2 HRS 37 MIN 05 SEC
CURRENT RECORD

|SEAN LEARY|
Now the record's at a point,
at least for us,

|SEAN LEARY|
where to push it further
it's quite dangerous.

|DEAN POTTER|
I can't sleep the night before.

|SEAN LEARY|
And I meet up with Dean

|SEAN LEARY|
and it's just this crazy,
nervous, intense energy.

|SEAN LEARY|
You can see the Nose
just above you, you know.

|SEAN LEARY|
It suddenly it appears out
of the darkness and you're like,

|SEAN LEARY|
"Holy shit,
we're gonna climb up there".

|SEAN LEARY|
So we've basically done
a rehearsal

|SEAN LEARY|
in our minds
of the entire route.

|DEAN POTTER|
Our rack is ridiculously small.

|DEAN POTTER|
We don't even take anything
to eat or anything to drink.

|VOICE AUDIO|
It is 6:26, stopwatch.

|DEAN POTTER|
Before I go for it,
I feel like I'm gonna vomit.

|DEAN POTTER|
You're gonna be fighting
for your life up there.

|DEAN POTTER|
Three, two, one, go.

|DEAN POTTER|
Nice and safe. Nice and safe.

|DEAN POTTER|
When we get on the rock,
we push each other.

|DEAN POTTER|
Looking good. Looking good.

|SEAN LEARY|
When you wanna be real fast, you
do what we call simul climbing.

|SEAN LEARY|
Both people are moving
at the same time.

|SEAN LEARY|
It gets super hardcore
because if the bottom guy falls,

|SEAN LEARY|
he pulls the top guy off.

|DEAN POTTER|
You can do it! Go for it!

|DEAN POTTER|
What we're doing isn't the way
you wanna teach rock climbing.

|SEAN LEARY|
And then it's Dean's turn

|SEAN LEARY|
and he's chainsawing his way up
the Stovelegs just like...

|DEAN POTTER|
I'm trying to gun it
as fast as possible

|DEAN POTTER|
but also super nervous
at that point.

|DEAN POTTER|
And I know if Sean falls,
I'll take a death fall.

|SEAN LEARY|
There you go.

|DEAN POTTER|
I'm panting, trying to keep up.

|DEAN POTTER|
Fighting the urge
just to yak.

|DEAN POTTER|
Half hour into it, you're
incredibly tired being like,

|DEAN POTTER|
"I don't know if I'm gonna be
able to maintain this

|DEAN POTTER|
for the next pitch."

|DEAN POTTER|
But you've got 20 pitches
above you.

|SEAN LEARY|
Do it.

|DEAN POTTER|
At the Boot, our strategy is
that I run out the entire crag,

|DEAN POTTER|
leaving no protection.

|DEAN POTTER|
I get up there

|DEAN POTTER|
and now there's just a clean
rope for Sean to swing over.

|DEAN POTTER|
Okay, make it super tight!

|DEAN POTTER|
At that point, there's not even
time to put Sean on belay.

|DEAN POTTER|
I just hold the rope
with my hands

|DEAN POTTER|
and hope
he doesn't bounce too hard.

|SEAN LEARY/DEAN POTTER|
-Got?
-Got it!

|DEAN POTTER|
As Sean swings across
for like over 100-feet.

|DEAN POTTER|
Go!

|DEAN POTTER|
Here!

|DEAN POTTER|
We're faster!

|SEAN LEARY|
What?

|DEAN POTTER|
We are going good.
We're faster than before.

|DEAN POTTER|
We're an hour two! We're good!

|SEAN LEARY|
And then it's my turn to lead

|SEAN LEARY|
and then I've gotta summon
the energy again

|SEAN LEARY|
to be like punching it.

|DEAN POTTER|
Sean, at that point,
runs it out 200-feet.

|DEAN POTTER|
Then Sean is going through
the Great Roof.

|SEAN LEARY|
Starting to get tired,
really starting to feel it.

|SEAN LEARY|
Then we have the most technical
part of the climb to go.

|SEAN LEARY|
I just want to keep
a steady pace.

|SEAN LEARY|
Everything is gonna have
to go perfectly.

|SEAN LEARY|
Catch!

|SEAN LEARY|
Any little thing
is gonna slow you down.

|DEAN POTTER|
One second, Sean.

|DEAN POTTER|
It was just like
the most beginner move ever.

|DEAN POTTER|
Jamming the jumar
against the knot.

|DEAN POTTER|
Jumar's stuck. Hold on.
I'm trying.

|SEAN LEARY|
The speed game, right, it's like
when it gets to that level,

|SEAN LEARY|
just some little drama.

|SEAN LEARY|
Dean's jumar
jamming into the knot.

|SEAN LEARY|
Some little thing happening

|SEAN LEARY|
can make you not even close
to the record.

|DEAN POTTER|
Sorry, Sean. The jumar's stuck.

|SEAN LEARY|
All right, just take your time.
We'll make up for it.

|SEAN LEARY|
And then I saw him
biting at it with his teeth

|SEAN LEARY|
and I was like,
"Oh, no. this isn't good."

|SEAN LEARY|
I mean, we were so close.
We're so on the edge.

|SEAN LEARY|
And that's part of the game.

|DEAN POTTER|
Fuck.

|DEAN POTTER|
And I thought that we didn't
have the record anymore.

|DEAN POTTER|
I'm getting it. I'm sorry.

|DEAN POTTER|
At that point we both knew

|DEAN POTTER|
that we had to pick it up
and go for it.

|DEAN POTTER|
There you go.

|SEAN LEARY|
You know, I had a nice little
break, which probably helped.

|SEAN LEARY|
And then we were able to
keep going after that.

|DEAN POTTER|
I go as fast as I can up
the Pancake Flake

|DEAN POTTER|
with this huge loop of rope.

|DEAN POTTER|
Far above, Sean's on like,
5.11 or 11 plus climbing.

|DEAN POTTER|
I'm cruising through 5.10
or 10 plus climbing.

|DEAN POTTER|
There's between 60 and 80 feet
of rope dangling below me

|DEAN POTTER|
and it's a guaranteed horrendous
fall for him if he blows it.

|SEAN LEARY|
You're up there and you're
just getting super pumped

|SEAN LEARY|
but you can't let go because
you don't have any gear in.

|DEAN POTTER|
Know that if he stays relaxed,
he won't fall.

|DEAN POTTER|
Once we get up
to the upper corners,

|DEAN POTTER|
the last like 10 pitches,
we're just giving it.

|DEAN POTTER|
At that point, 25 pitches in,

|DEAN POTTER|
having sprinted, you know,
arms are cramping.

|DEAN POTTER|
This hand jam that foot,
don't slip.

|DEAN POTTER|
You just need to be able to
punch out 5.11

|DEAN POTTER|
after you've been
climbing thousands of feet.

|DEAN POTTER|
Sean!

|DEAN POTTER|
Get me on belay, Sean.
Getting real here.

|DEAN POTTER|
Please.

|SEAN LEARY|
Good job. You're on, bro.

|DEAN POTTER|
You're just redlining it.

|DEAN POTTER|
Your lungs are gonna explode.

|DEAN POTTER|
And then you find out
you're like a couple minutes

|DEAN POTTER|
from breaking the record
and you have to try harder.

|DEAN POTTER|
No gear! Don't fall!

|DEAN POTTER|
it's just like you're so tired

|DEAN POTTER|
that it feels like
racing at maximum speed,

|DEAN POTTER|
but in reality, we're kind
of crawling over the top.
